overview: This subject provides an introduction to process work in process engineering, focusing specifically on process safety and sustainability. Material taught in other chemical engineering subjects will be reinforced via a series of assignments in which ill-defined and open-ended process engineering problems will be tackled. Both hypothetical and real case studies from the process engineering field are used throughout the subject.

Several assessment tasks combine to form a capstone project. Within this project students, in teams of three or four, perform design tasks related to the development of a Chemical Process Engineering facility. This capstone project culminates in an Environmental Effects Statement assignment. Several industry speakers, from the process engineering and environmental areas, talk and provide content to aid with this assignment.
ilo: Approach and solve open-ended design problems in the field of process engineering
Place problems being solved within the context in which engineering processes take place
Be able to evaluate data from a range of sources to allow a coherent professional engineering technical report to be prepared
Gain advanced skills in the use of process engineering software
Be able to lay out a Chemical Process Engineering facility
Design and modify Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams
Access and use Australian Standards for equipment design
Use pinch and energy analysis techniques to minimise plantwide energy consumption
Perform HAZOP and QRA safety analyses
Use sustainable engineering techniques, such as Life Cycle Analysis
generic_skills: Ability to apply knowledge of basic science and engineering fundamentals
Ability to communicate effectively, not only with engineers but also with the community at large
Ability to undertake problem identification, formulation and solution
Ability to utilise a systems approach to design and operational performance
Ability to function effectively as an individual and in multi-disciplinary and multi-cultural teams
Understanding of the social, cultural, global and environmental responsibilities of the professional engineer, and the need for sustainable development.

Prerequisites.content: Note: these can be taken concurrently (at the same time)

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Seven in-class Assignments, worth 50% (in total), conducted in groups of 3-4 students, each to be completed within a 3-hour workshop session. Preparation time of approximately 4-5 hours for each workshop (including pre-reading and additional research tasks). All Intended Learning Outcomes (ILOs) are addressed in these assignments. Delivered throughout the semester starting from Week 1. Workshops use both allocated and self-selected team assignments, with peer assessment employed to moderate individual grades

One take home written report, conducted individually, worth 15%, and due in Weeks 4-5 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 10 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables). Overall time commitment of 15-20 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 6, 8

One take home written report conducted individually, worth 10%, and due in Weeks 7-8 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 6 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of approximately 10-13 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 10

One take home written report conducted individually, worth 15%, and due in Week 10 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 10 A4 pages (min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of 15-20 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 9

One take home written report, conducted in groups of 3-4 students, worth 10%, and due in Week 12 of the semester, consisting of a maximum of 34 A4 pages for the group (page limit based on a group of 4, min 11pt font, single spaced, including any appendices, figures and tables.) Overall time commitment of 10-13 hours. ILOs addressed in this assignment: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 12

date_times.contact_hours: 1 x two hour lecture + 1 x three hour workshop per week
